and I have the extreme good fortune to
be leaving the AWS robotics team so
let's talk a little bit about robotics

about how is Amazon been involved with
robotics our company applies a wide
range of innovative technologies
throughout our fulfillment centers
including robotics today we have over a
hundred thousand robots being used
throughout our fulfillment centers in 26
fulfillment centers around the world
that's pretty cool so why don't we also
take a moment and talk a little bit
about what is cloud robotics for folks
that may not be familiar with that term
sure it's really about augmenting or
complementing the functionality the
software the capability of a robot no
longer as a robot limited buyer the
compute power or the software it has
installed and instead it can take
advantage of cloud services we think of
a robot is anything that senses computes
and then takes action and so if you go
through those and think about sensing a
robot now can actually use machine
learning services such as Pauly and Lex
to listen to what people are saying to
respond backwards boys use a service
like recognition to actually recognize
what it's seeing in its video feed in
terms of computing it can take it a
constraint video to the cloud and use
recognition to understand what it's
seeing do complex navigation and so
basically every aspect of a robot from
sensing computing to acting can be
augmented with cloud services that's
pretty cool thank you for that really
good detailed explanation so I'm kind of
curious what do you think are some of
the problems that robotics can help
solve today so we talked to over
hundreds of customers as we're building
AWS Robo maker and what we found is that
a lot of these developers struggled just
to build the robotics application and a
lot of that is really undifferentiated
heavy lifting
from getting a development environment
set up to being able to pull much put

then how to update the robot what sits

Robo maker and you got a little bit of a

do you want to tell us how customers are
using Robo maker for example so one of
my customers is called robot care
systems they're robots called Leah Leah
is a walker robot for the elderly and
the disabled Leah doesn't have a lot of
processing power on and compute power on
it all of the sensors are being used to
help make sure the patient is steady and
the walker avoids all obstacles they've
been able to integrate poly and lex into
Leah
so now customers their customers can

respond they're integrating machine
learning so they can do predictive
models to forecast the patient's health
make Leah more stable and make Leah more
smarter for them cool so it looks like
we might be running out of time we might

so we are at an inflection point and the
next two to three years you can expect
to see mobile robotics and logistics to
go up by a factor of 10 and we believe
the AWS Cod is going to prove to be one
